content: What famous author, known for his works on Middle Earth, was also a professor of Anglo-Saxon at Oxford?

You're referring to J.R.R. Tolkien, the renowned author best known for his epic high fantasy works "The Hobbit" and "The Lord of the Rings" trilogy. These novels are set in the richly detailed world of Middle-earth, which he created over many years.

Tolkien was indeed a professor of Anglo-Saxon (also known as Old English) at Oxford University. His academic background deeply influenced his writing, as he drew upon ancient myths, legends, and languages to craft the intricate cultures and histories of Middle-earth's inhabitants.

His scholarly work included editing and translating ancient texts, such as "Glossary" for the Anglo-Saxon poem "Sir Gawain and the Green Knight," and his own original research into Old and Middle English literature. This expertise is evident in the linguistic complexity of his invented languages for Middle-earth, like Elvish and Dwarvish, which have their own grammars and vocabularies.

Tolkien's academic career and his passion for mythology and language are inextricably linked to his literary achievements, making him one of the most influential figures in modern fantasy literature.
